thread.title: Falling interest rates on savings accounts, how to find a good deal
thread.title_full: Falling interest rates on savings accounts, how to find a good deal

author: Sophie Elsworth MoneysaverHQ deputy editor
title: Falling interest rates on savings accounts, how to find a good deal
text:
FALLING interest rates on savings accounts means those with cash in the bank really need to hunt around for a decent deal.
The cash rate has remained has plummeted to a record low of two per cent and while this is great news for borrowers it’s the polar opposite for savers.
New data from financial comparison site Mozo shows that, for mildly decent returns, the highest rates market come with strings attached.
Its data shows the best savings account on the market is the RAMS Saver account which has a special rate of 3.6 per cent if the customer deposits at least $200 every month and makes no withdrawals.
The monthly interest returns on $5000 are $15 a month.
If they don’t stick to these rules they’ll get a return of just two per cent and monthly interest payments of just $8.33.
Antonia Quinlivan, 26, has saved up $3000 so she can move out of her parents' home in Sydney. Picture: Christian Gilles Source: News Corp Australia
Mozo spokeswoman Caroline Thomas concedes that savings accounts are doing very little for customers so it’s critical to take the time to find the highest rate possible.
“Standard savings rates are far from delivering big returns, so accounts with an introductory or bonus rate is where the best deals are right now,’’ she says.
“In fact, you could double your interest by taking up one of these offers.”
Then you can move to another account once the introductory rate ends.
But for savers who also have a home loan or other debts, she says they are far better off parking it in a mortgage offset account to reduce the mortgage interest costs or use the cash to pay down debts.
This is because the amount of interest payable on a mortgage or credit card far outweighs the amount you can earn from a savings account.
Solicitor Antonia Quinlivan, 26, is moving out of her mother’s home next month and says she’s been sticking to a strict savings plan despite only reaping small returns on her cash.
“My goal was to save about $3000 so I could afford to move out of home so I was putting about $600 to $1000 away every month,’’ she says.
“I’m only getting about 2.25 per cent on my savings, I went with an account my friends recommended.”
She says if she had a day-to-day account with the same bank as well as her savings account and deposited a minimum of $1000 into the account each month she would get a higher rate.
